course.subject: LANG
course.name: Effective Chinese Communication
course.description: This course seeks to enhance the market competitiveness of HKUST graduates by making them effective users of spoken Putonghua and Standard Written Chinese in meeting communicative needs in academic, social and professional contexts. The course materials and activities help students acquire fluency and accuracy in the use of Chinese by engaging them in authentic communication tasks based on real-life situations and needs. Students' mastery of Putonghua phonology and Chinese syntax and lexis will also be enhanced through in-class teaching and outside class practice.
course.exclusions: Level 4 or above in HKDSE Chinese, LANG 1114 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1115 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1116 (prior to 2017-18), LANG 1117, LANG 1118, LANG 1120, LANG 1121, LANG 1122, LANG 1123, LANG 1124, LANG 1125, LANG 1126, LANG 1127

reviews.author: drew.ng
reviews.title: If you took IB 2nd lang, fake your interview and dont join this.
reviews.comment_content: As the title says, I died in this course. When you are being interviewed cos you did IB/AS by her, don't even answer in mandarin. This course was full of local IB students and guys from BEIJING???? bro I just want to pass, I did not sign up to get humiliated. (I got a strong level 6 in IB 2nd lang mando).
reviews.comment_teaching: Teaching was alright. She loves to set you on the spot and I basically struggled to read a whole paragraph while she just waited. (She interviewed me and I made the mistake of even knowing how to reply in Mandarin).
reviews.comment_grading: I dont remember but since she put me in this course, I think she saw how I 'improved' so I did average.
reviews.comment_workload: Group work - unless you got someone who did local school IB, youre basically as useless as spongebob in his driving test. I got carried hard since I'm basically blind in mando.

reviews.author: mxyh1904
reviews.title: Would not recommend taking this course
reviews.comment_content: Total of three units, which are all from the Lang textbook. Covers HKUST, technology, and social/environmental issues. All course content is covered in Mandarin.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor's teaching style is really subjective. She tries her best to engage students but isn't very clear when explaining things, which is especially true when explaining assignments or giving assignment feedback. For our first project, we asked for feedback and corrected our project based on her advice, but when we got our assignment back, the critiques were all on the things she told us to change.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading was really strange...We never actually received assignment grades past the first assignment but somehow she got to a letter grade. Also, her grading is super subjective and doesn't really have a lot to do with your actual chinese proficiency. We spent maybe 13/18 classes discussing presentation order and the difference between different word synonyms and that is honestly probably what you'll get graded on in the end :/
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is pretty light. It's mostly just the projects for each unit, but if you screw those up say goodbye to your Lang grade...

If you don't do the readings it's honestly fine

reviews.author: hautonjt
reviews.title: Take it like a man
reviews.comment_content: The content is largely similar to LANG1113. It includes stuff that explains how chinese writing is structured, how to formulate the introduction, conclusion, etc. There was a unit on HKUST, a unit on analytical report writing, and a unit on understanding society. If any of these things interest you, it will probably make this course easier to stomach. Perhaps you might be able to close your eyes and swallow it like a bitter pill. If these things don't interest you, bury your face in your hands and ask yourself why you chose HKUST as your university AND barely qualify as a person that knows chinese.
reviews.comment_teaching: Of all the aspects of LANG1113I, this is the thing I like the most. The pace of learning is actually quite reasonable, and there were a couple of friendly teaching assistants that made the class fun (or as fun as it's going to get for such a GREAT course). If you know simplified chinese, this part is going to be pretty good, as all the powerpoint slides are in simplified. If you are one of those people that only know traditional chinese characters, well, good luck.
reviews.comment_grading: A good thing about LANG1113I is that apparently the grading of the course is not grouped with the regular LANG1113 course. However, this does not mean the course is going to be a free A. In fact, the grade is probably going to be quite painful, especially if you are a high-achiever in other subjects. Don't expect a good grade without any work. You're taking this course. Don't expect a silver lining.
reviews.comment_workload: Since this course is LANG1113I, I'm assuming that your chinese writing and oral skills are not stellar. Perhaps your vocabulary is not that impressive, or your pronunciation is (quite) a bit off. The good thing is that you get the option to type essays on your computer using whatever input method you like. The bad thing is the fact that you'll need to put in quite a bit of effort to prepare for the presentations. The REALLY bad thing is that you're going to also do a group discussion that you can't really prepare for. Good luck!

reviews.author: 13chanj5
reviews.comment_content:
You don't get to choose this course, you have to attend an interview and they assign you the course afterwards.

This course uses the content of LANG1113, a course intended for actual chinese people, and cuts expectations, reduces the workload for students who have chinese as a second language.

As for quality of the content, it's pretty much every language class you've ever taken, with writing, speaking and reading exercises loosely based around stuff in HKUST. As a result, its as boring as every language class you've ever taken.

Almost all of the grade is based around your ability to write and speak, as well as attendance.
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is super chill, and the atmosphere is good enough. She's willing to help you improve your essays and stuff as well.
reviews.comment_grading: Honestly, I feel that a large portion of her grading is based on her opinion of you. So if you give her a bad impression, your grade will dip a bit. If you're active in class, put effort into your essays and presentations, she'll give you a nicer grade.
reviews.comment_workload: There isn't a ton of work honestly. All you gotta do is show up for tutorials and pretend to give a shit.

reviews.author: Leo Lai
reviews.title: Super patience and helpful
reviews.comment_content: As far as I am concern, the content should be the same as the normal Lang 1113. So you have to do two group presentations and two writing(one mid-term which is finished at home, and one final which is conducted like normal exams.
reviews.comment_teaching: Ms. Mok is happy to review all the your presentation as well as writing before you have to hand them in. Which is extremely helpful to say the least and you would be stupid to not to take advantage of that. (She spends a lot of her own time to help studnts.)
reviews.comment_grading: I would say it is very fair and if you put in more work, she will give you a better grade. On the other hand, if your Chinese is not up to the standard of the rest of the class, she is always happy to assist and shows a huge amount of leniency when it comes to grading.
reviews.comment_workload: Despite being a language class, do not underestimate its workload. The group presenations require a lot of time and effort if you want to get a good grade.

reviews.author: ChingChongCheng
reviews.title: Easy ting
reviews.comment_content: Content is just 2 presentation and 2 writing. Nothing major. Make sure you attend classes and find a suitable groupmate.
reviews.comment_teaching: Quite boring but she is nice. Doesn't care about anything and is always happy to help; although it is hard to understand her.
reviews.comment_grading: Really depends on her perception on you. I got a 4, some 5s, mostly 6s and two 7s overall and managed to get an A.
reviews.comment_workload: For me it wasnt too bad. Writing was a pain in the ass, took me more than 6 hours to do. Presentation was fine cos I had good groupmates.

reviews.author: hs
reviews.comment_content:
Content:
-Oral presentations
-Writing skills

Format:
Biweekly lectures where you don't actually learn much. She goes through her powerpoint slides and sometimes works through problems in the textbook together with the students.

Assignments:
-One to two practice essays for her to gauge your writing level
-Writing assignment describing a course at HKUST
-Presentation on some aspect of HKUST life
-Group debate about some social issue
-Final essay on some social issue

Attendance:
-Attendance taken
reviews.comment_teaching: The teacher is friendly but it's unclear what she wants at times. Don't be afraid to ask for clarification or book an appointment with her to assignment help. Powerpoints and assignments are available in both simplified and traditional Chinese.
reviews.comment_grading:
Participation: 10%
Presentation on HKUST life: 20%
Writing assignment: 20%
Group debate 25%
Final in class essay: 25%

Grading is fair, but expect to put in some serious effort if you want to get high grades. You can ask her for input about your work before submitting it, and she'll be glad to help you improve it.
reviews.comment_workload: Heavy workload. Fortunately, you don't have to be able to actually write chinese characters to do well on this course. All of the assignments can be done on a computer via keyboard input. ­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­­
